issue.title: Change logger/sink configuration at runtime?
issue.body:
Is there a straightforward way to change the logger configuration (or sink configuration) at runtime?

I generally set up my main logger with a rolling file sink to print out critical errors (especially at startup) as this works in most scenarios. Independently of what type of application I have (service, website, console), I only need to ensure the file system is write-able and I'm good to go.

```
// dummy
var logfilepath = GetLogFilePath(Assembly.GetEntryAssembly());
Log.Logger = new LoggerConfiguration()
                        .WriteTo.RollingFile(logfilepath)
                        .CreateLogger();
Log.Debug("It works!");
```

However, I also would like to log into other sources that are more prone to fail at startup (e.g. databases when wrong connection strings are given). So what I would like to achieve is the following:
1. Set up a simple, stable logging sink for first startup
2. Set up e.g. database, log everything related to it
3. If e.g. database is up and running, add database sink to serilog.

The only way I see to accomplish this is:
1. Create a logger configuration
2. Do stuff
3. Create a new logger configuration and overwrite the existing one.

Dummy code:

```
var logfilepath = GetLogFilePath(Assembly.GetEntryAssembly());
Log.Logger = new LoggerConfiguration()
                        .WriteTo.RollingFile(logfilepath)
                        .CreateLogger();
Log.Debug("It works!");

Log.Debug("Setting up database with {ConnectionString}", connectionString);

Log.Logger = new LoggerConfiguration()
                            .WriteTo.RollingFile(logfilepath)
                            .WriteTo.SomeDatabaseSink(connectionString)
                            .CreateLogger();
```

Is there a cleaner, more straightforward approach to change the logger configuration other than overwriting it completely?

body:
Hi Casey, thanks for the info. Good to validate there's more than one scenario for this.

To avoid too much version compatibility juggling, I'll tackle the core Serilog change ASAP, probably in the next few days. Some help propagating this out through the various sinks would be great, if you're still keen to jump in once the foundation is laid!
Sounds good. Happy to help where I can.

issue.title: Add a `levelSwitch` parameter to all sink configuration methods

body: The foundations are there in #511 - a little stalled on deciding how it should go out (1.5, 1.6, 2.0, ...) - thoughts appreciated on that one.

@nblumhardt I've implemented the functionality in the Seq Sink and while testing various scenarios noticed that if you are logging with an API key to Seq and have the min level set to something against the Seq API Key, if you then delete that key Seq will continue to report back to the Seq Sink the previous API key min level. I would have expected it to start reporting back null. Bug in Seq or by design?

issue.title: Reset reported minimum level when an API key is deleted

repository.name: seq-tickets
repository.description: Issues, design discussions and feature roadmap for the Seq log server

issue.body:
Via: https://github.com/serilog/serilog/issues/505#issuecomment-132688515

When an API key is deleted, the minimum logging level it was assigned is still cached and reported to apps that log with the deleted key.

body: @caseymarcallen thanks for the heads-up. Sounds low-pri, but likely a bug. Created https://github.com/continuousit/seq-releases/issues/334. Cheers!

issue.title: Add a `levelSwitch` parameter to all sink configuration methods (v2)
Adding support for LevelSwitch for this sink?

repository.name: serilog-sinks-azure-analytics
repository.description: Serilog sink which writes to Azure analytics

issue.body: We have a configuration setup where we can dynamically change the logging level of different sinks. However, this is not possible at the moment with Azure analytics sink. But available in file and console sinks.
